comment._content: this is Chick Gandil, later a character in 1919 Black Sox Scandal en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chick_Gandil www.baseball-reference.com/g/gandich01.shtml

comment.author: 11115299@N06
comment._content: genious b&w picture. love these old pics.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the player identification. However, the Society for American Baseball Research looked at this photograph in 2006 and decided it wasn’t Chick Gandil. We’ve added a note to our record to document this.

comment.author: 27109792@N00
comment._content:
If the photographer confused this for gandil, then at least we know that it's some other player on the same team, right...


so, we're looking at the 1913 Washington AL team, not NL

other details,:these are the road uniforms.

comment.author: 46533988@N00
comment._content: It could be a young Walter Johnson.

comment.author: 27109792@N00
comment._content: that reversed date says 4-24-13  on that day the Senators played the Red Sox in Washington at Griffith Stadium

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: I think this is another view of Eddie Foster, taken just before or after this photo. Foster played third base in 1913, and Gandil played first base. Could the second guy in this photo be shortstop George McBride?

comment.author: 11427496@N00
comment._content: The player in the background appears to be Chick Gandil. The player in the foreground does appear to be Eddie Foster. -- Found in a search. (?)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
Thanks to all for the continued efforts in identification of the Washington Senators players in this photograph. The player in the background is somewhat indistinct, so a positive identification may be quite hard to come by.  

whyaduck: While this photograph could be Eddie Foster due to similarity in appearance, the other photograph of Foster you've linked to shows him in a different uniform shirt (shorter sleeves on the identified image), so it is not as likely to be taken at the same time. 
 
We'll keep an eye on this photograph to see if further confirmation turns up as to the identities of the players.  Thanks again to all for the continued interest.

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Oops. I didn't even notice the different sleeve lengths.

comment.author: 34445950@N04
comment._content: It is Ray Morgan for sure, no doubt, it is him - trust me!

comment.author: 33572458@N05
comment._content: The folks at Society for American Baseball Research agree that this is Ray Morgan based on comparisons to other photos of him.  Thanks bmarlowe1 and everyone for weighing in.
